Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Hardness Strength and Ductility Tester for Field Assessment of Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will support the technological refinement and concomitant commercialization of the first accurate and portable instrument that can perform in the field nondestructive test for hardness, strength and ductility of existing infrastructure. The material properties measured include yield strength, work hardening exponent and ultimate tensile strength of metals, specifically steel. The on-shore oil and gas pipeline transmission industry has pressing needs for non-destructive tests because of the aging infrastructure, national need for energy, and recent explosions and leaks that have cost lives and billions in remediation. Although transmission pipelines have low failure rate per mile of assets, pipeline operators are asked to proactively enhance pipeline integrity where they do not have all the necessary strength data. Therefore, there is an immediate need to verify strength during the 80,000 excavations done each year so that the life of these costly assets can be extended by identifying and remediating the few sections that are vulnerable within the extended network of 300,000 miles of pipelines. Pipe cut-outs and hydrostatic pressure tests are alternatives to nondestructive testing, but both damage the asset and require expensive and complex service interruption.

The overall technical objective of the Phase II work is to perform the necessary research and development to enable the development of engineering specifications, system integration, and validation of the instrument to successfully perform valuable nondestructive testing to provide precise and accurate material property data. The research and development program includes three milestones, each enabling the implementation of the research into design and manufacturing of beta test units. Milestone 1 is to enable full instrument functionality under adverse field environments such as vibration, moisture, and extreme temperatures. Milestone 2 is to perform the necessary work for designing ruggedized field units. Completion of this milestone will enhance the capability for initial field testing services. Milestone 3 is to develop the knowledge to fully and reliably integrate the system, validate the sub-systems, and package it for manufacturing. The overall goal is to enable the company to have the necessary knowledge and experience to enter the instrument market with a leasing program for use in pipeline inspections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aging infrastructure is a maintenance cost, and risk liability across many industries. Metal corrosion and fatigue results in billions of dollars of  repair costs and replacements in industries such as defense, energy, chemical processing and transportation. This cost increases when factoring in the potential for the loss of life, costs associated with environmental damage, and public opinion. The oil and gas industry faces a particularly pressing challenge to assess the integrity of 300,000 miles of aging transmission pipelines for which financing for replacement is limited to a small fraction of the assets at risk. About half of these pipelines were installed prior to 1970 and are operating under high pressure. Many do not have complete records of their material properties or their capacity to withstand operating pressure. Per new federal regulation, any of these assets must be evaluated for their material strength because of the lack of complete construction records and variability in material quality that was not all captured in the original quality testing.

With assistance from the NSF SBIR Phase I and II grants, Massachusetts Materials Technologies LLC (MMT) has developed unique, portable, and nondestructive instruments that provide oil and gas pipeline operators accurate strength data at a fraction of the cost of current methods which often require service interruption and physically destructive cutouts for offsite laboratory tests. The revolutionary Hardness, Strength, and Ductility (HSD) Tester is a portable and nondestructive instrument which measures the strength properties of pipeline steel and determines the welding process used to manufacture longitudinal seams.. This portable instrument has already been used to support the life extension and material verification of oil and gas pipeline assets initiated through field testing services provided by MMT technicians and now primarily through third party inspection service companies that purchased HSD Testers from MMT.

In-parallel with the commercialization of the HSD and as part of NSF-SBIR Phase IIB funding, MMT successfully completed an enhancement of the HSD to measure the weld toughness for pipelines with a longitudinal seam and a proof of concept of a second, novel, nondestructive testing device called the Nondestructive Toughness Tester (NDTT) which will measure material fracture toughness of homogeneous materials such as the pipe body or other structural assets in different industries.

Since receiving the NSF-SBIR Phase I grant in 2016, MMT’s commercial sales have nearly doubled each year reaching annual revenues of $3M in 2020. The NSF-SBIR program has been a cornerstone in the technological, commercial and financial success of MMT. MMT is now able to accelerate the progress on the team mission to support economical and safe life extension of aging pipeline assets.
